title: Asian Football Chief To Stand For FIFA Top Job
text:
Switch to US Edition Asian Football Chief To Stand For FIFA Top Job Sheikh Salman al-Khalifa's push for the presidency - revealed by Sky sources - may spell the end for Michael Platini's chances. 23:38, UK, Thursday 15 October 2015 Sheik Salman had been a key supporter of Mr Platini's Share by email By Paul Kelso, Sports Correspondent in Nyon Sheikh Salman Bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa, the Bahraini president of the Asian Football Confederation, is to stand for the FIFA presidency, sources have told Sky News. 
The move by the 49 year-old member of Bahrain's royal family makes him the favourite to become leader of world football's governing body, and could end any prospect of Michel Platini succeeding Sepp Blatter. 
Sheikh Salman, who is expected to confirm his candidacy next week following an emergency meeting of FIFA's executive committee, has only been a member of the FIFA body since 2013, having won the presidency of the AFC in the same year. 
Until recently he was Platini's most influential supporter, urging more than 50 Asian FIFA members to back the Frenchman's candidacy. Sheik Salman will now be seen as the favourite for the president 
But with support in Europe drifting away from Platini following a police investigation into a disputed Â£1.35m payment from Sepp Blatter, Salman has resolved to stand after weeks of deliberation. 
His candidacy emerged after a day of fractious discussion among European football leaders at UEFA headquarters in Nyon ended with the only a lukewarm expression of support for Platini. Play video "FIFA Suspends Blatter And Platini" Video: FIFA Suspends Blatter And Platini 
UEFA leaders had gathered to discuss his position, which has been thrown into question by the Swiss investigation into the Blatter payment that left both men banned for 90 days. 
In a statement they agreed only to support Platini's right "to due process" and to clear his name, but there was no mention of his FIFA candidacy. 
Sky News understands there were clear divisions among European nations, with England, Germany, Holland and the Scandinavian nations believing it will be difficult for Platini to recover his credibility. 
UEFA did urge a swift resolution to the process begun by FIFA's ethics committee, but with the deadline for election candidates to declare falling on October 26 and Platini likely to be excluded, some wanted to create room for an alternative candidate. 
Significantly UEFA decided not to press ahead with calls for a delay to the election, an acknowledgment of Platini's waning support that had already seen some European figures sound out Sheikh Salman and his supporters in Asia. Play video "FIFA President Faces Calls To Quit" Video: FIFA President Faces Calls To Quit 
The Bahraini is understood to have canvassed opinion in Asia, Europe and the Americas and believes he can become a consensus candidate. 
It remains to be seen if an alternative European candidate steps forward. Holland's Michael Van Praag, a candidate in May's election, is thought to be considering his position. 
Sheikh Salman's major contribution to FIFA since his elevation to the executive committee was to lead the group that negotiated the shifting of the 2022 Qatar World Cup from summer to winter. 
An unpopular project, it doubtless proved a crash course in the machinations of FIFA politics. It is a world with which he is about to become a great deal more familiar. Promoted Stories
